section.name: namespace
section.p: In general, a namespace is a named group of names that are mutually unique. The same name has exactly one meaning within a namespace, but in another namespace it may also occur and may have an other meaning there.

In the Hippo repository a namespace contains document types (CMS doctypes). Documents and folders in the repository are not part of any namespace. However, documents always are of a particular document type and that document type is part of some namespace. If you perform the action 'update all content' on a namespace, the contents may change of all documents that are of a document type in that namespace.

subsection.name: Namespace name format rules
subsection.p: In the Hippo repository, namespace names have the form of a URI (URL) with as last part a version number. Namespace names in the form of a URI (URL) are quite common as URI's (and therefor URL's) are supposed to be unique in the whole world.

subsection.name: full names
subsection.p: As namespace names are very long, it would be cumbersome to include the namespace name in each name that belongs to the namespace. It should however always be clear to which namespace a name belongs. Therefor, a namespace prefix is defined for the namespace, which is short. subsection.name: Namespace name format rules
subsection.p: In the Hippo repository, namespace names have the form of a URI (URL) with as last part a version number.

Namespace names in the form of a URI (URL) are quite common as URI's (and therefor URL's) are supposed to be unique in the whole world. The URL does not have to exist, but if your organization owns a website, it is good practice to use an URL your organization owns, as that guarantees it's uniqueness.
The version number will be automatically increased by the CMS when changes are made to the namespace like making a change to one of its document types (CMS doctypes).

subsection.name: usage
subsection.p: In the Hippo repository a namespace contains CMS doctypes (document types).

subsection.name: More explanation about the concept
subsection.p: Namespaces reflect how people normally talk: context dependent. E.g. if you talk to your spouse about 'the children', you do not mean the same children as when somebody else talks to his or her spouse about 'the children'. The phrase 'the children' refers to different children, depending on context. A namespace is such a context. Your family name is a namespace.
